Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology & Engineering CAS 1219 Zhongguan West Road Ningbo 315201, Zhejiang China Graphical abstract Catalytic oxidation is a promising manner to produce 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) from 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). This review summarizes the progress in the thermocatalysis, electrocatalysis, and photocatalysis for FDCA production, including catalyst screening, synthesis processes, and reaction mechanism. Biomass conversion to value-added chemicals has received tremendous attention for solving global warming issues and fossil fuel depletion. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is a key bio-based platform molecule to produce many useful organic chemicals by oxidation, hydrogenation, polymerization, and ring-opening reactions. Among all derivatives, the oxidation product 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is a promising alternative to petroleum-based terephthalic acid for the synthesis of biodegradable plastics. This review analytically discusses the recent progress in the thermocatalytic, electrocatalytic, and photocatalytic oxidation of HMF into FDCA, including catalyst screening, synthesis processes, and reaction mechanism. Rapid fundamental advances may be possible in non-precious metal and metal-free catalysts that are highly efficient under the base-free conditions, and external field-assisted processes like electrochemical or photoelectrochemical cells. Keywords 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural 2,5-Furandicarboxylic acid Catalytic oxidation Mechanism 1 Introduction Both drastic depletion of fossil resources and carbon emission reduction have stimulated considerable efforts to explore new renewable energy. Biomass as a sustainable energy and substance resource is chiefly derived from carbon dioxide fixed by the plant photosynthesis [1–4]. One crucial route of biomass conversion is to transform the plentiful and cheap hexoses (glucose and fructose) into important platform chemicals. 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), a versatile intermediate dehydrated from abundant C6 carbohydrates, can be converted to high value-added chemicals (Scheme 1 ) by oxidation, hydrogenation, polymerization, and ring-opening reactions of its furan ring, aldehyde and alcohol groups [5,6]. For instance, the oxidation products of HMF comprise 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA), 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA) and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), which could be widely used in fine chemicals, pharmacy, chiral catalysis, molecular recognition, and polymers [7–10]. Especially, as one of the top-12 value-added platform chemicals from biomass listed by the U.S. Department of Energy, FDCA is able to make up of the terephthalic acid, a large-scale monomer of the commercial polyethylene terephthalate [4,11–13]. Oxidation of HMF can be carried out by stoichiometric reaction with strong oxidants like potassium permanganate, but this often led to both consumed feedstock and waste residue. The catalytic oxidation route can significantly reduce the reactive energy barrier to allow the reaction going ahead under mild reaction conditions. Meanwhile, the reaction pathway can be modulated by optimizing the catalyst components to reach a high yield of one target product. Extensive efforts have been made to optimize catalyst structure with the gradually becoming clear comprehension of the reaction mechanism, but present catalytic technologies still cannot meet the strict requirements of chemical industries. Regardless, an environmentally friendly route by using water as the solvent and oxygen or air as oxidants is considered as the most attractive choice. This review aims to give a general overview of development and challenges to promote the industrial production of FDCA from HMF oxidation. 2 Thermocatalytic oxidation of HMF into FDCA Literature survey shows that the first work about FDCA production was conducted by Fittig and Heinzelmann in 1876 [12,14]. Aqueous HBr was used as both catalyst and solvent to dehydrate mucic acid (Scheme 2 a), but this method was restricted by serious corrosion of equipment, poor selectivity, and low FDCA yield. In 1951, Kuhn and co-workers [15] proposed a prospective route to synthesize FDCA in the acidic medium by using an uncommon conjugated hexose derivative as the reactant (Scheme 2b). Recent concerns on environmental protection and the atomic economy motivated a large number of researches on the catalytic oxidation of HMF that is derived from easily available carbohydrates like glucose, fructose, agar or cellulose. Especially, a pilot-plant demonstration with an annual productivity being up to 10,000 tons of HMF was recently completed by Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology and Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences in cooperation with Zhejiang Sugar Energy Technology Co., Ltd [16]. 2.1 Liquid alkali system 2.1.1 Single noble metal catalysts For FDCA production via catalytic oxidation of HMF, the choice of O2 or air as oxidant show economical and environmental advantages, which is highly consistent with the direction of sustainable development and the concept of green chemistry. As oxygen is not easily activated, noble metals (Au, Pt, Pd, and Ru) are often selected as heterogeneous catalysts for many oxidation processes including aerobic oxidation of alcohols, aldehydes, cyclohexane, and acrolein, due to their excellent ability to activate molecular oxygen (O2) [3]. In this section, liquid-phase oxidation systems employed green and clean oxidant together with single noble metal catalysts in nontoxic water are summarized. The critical reaction parameters over each catalyst reported recently are presented in Table 1 . Many studies and reviews revealed that Au catalysts are more active for the oxidation of aldehyde groups, whereas Pt and Pd catalysts are more active for the oxidation of alcohol groups [12,17–19]. It is profoundly meaningful to reveal the differences in catalytic activity, giving guidance for the audiences to choose active metal species. Although the reaction rates based on the molar noble metal are precise to describe the specific activity of catalysts, the structural parameters, including particle size, dispersion degree, and exposed facets, have significant influences on catalytic performance. Aim to screen active catalysts for the potential industrial production of FDCA, it is more appropriate to compare specific activity based on the mass of catalysts. Fig. 1 illustrates a comparison of reaction rates for HMF conversion and FDCA generation over all the supported catalysts presented in Table 1. Apparently, Pt catalysts are the most active catalysts, especially in low-temperature condition. Carbon supported Pd catalysts also show remarkable low-temperature activities, while Au catalysts tend to be applied at high temperatures for higher performances. This trend is consistent with the earlier comparative study, which demonstrated that Pt and Pd catalysts were more selective towards FDCA with 79% and 71% selectivity respectively, while Au catalysts required higher O2 pressures and base concentrations as well as much longer reaction time to reach the similar FDCA selectivity [17]. According to Fig. 1, Ru catalysts show low reaction rates in terms of HMF conversion and FDCA production though they run in higher temperatures, indicating their mass activities need to be improved. Nevertheless, Ru catalysts remain economically attractive because of their low price, usually as low as ~ 4% of that of Au and Pt costs per gram [20]. On the other hand, for a given noble metal, differences in activity arise mainly from the effect of the basic additives and the structural parameters of catalysts, as discussed in detail below. Efficiently catalytic oxidation of HMF to FDCA usually requires a certain amount of base (e.g. NaOH, NaHCO3, K2CO3) whose concentration significantly affects the yield of FDCA. Gorbanev et al. [18] found that the selectivities to both fully oxidized product FDCA and intermediate product HMFCA depended on the amount of added base. The yield of HMFCA was high relative to FDCA at full HMF conversion with low amounts of NaOH, whereas the conversion of HMF was only 13% with 12% HMFCA and 1% FDCA yields in the absence of the base. In the presence of an excess base, a 1 wt% Au/TiO2 catalyst could oxidize HMF into FDCA with 71% yield at 30 °C and 2 MPa oxygen for 18 h. Casanova and co-workers [21] obtained a nearly 100% yield of FDCA (65–130 °C, 1 MPa air, 8 h) using Au-CeO2 or Au-TiO2 catalysts with a molar ratio NaOH/HMF of 4. Besides the single oxide supports, HY zeolite supported Au nanoclusters exhibited a superior performance at a lower oxygen pressure and gave > 99% yield of FDCA under mild conditions (60 °C, 0.3 MPa O2) [22]. The authors concluded that the HY zeolite supercage restricted the agglomeration of Au nanoclusters and resulted in a modified electronic structure of Au nanoparticles by the interaction with the hydroxyl groups in the supercage. Interestingly, Davis et al. [17] found that, at low pH value, the supported Au catalysts mainly produced HMFCA with a high yield while carbon-supported Pt and Pd catalysts tended to generate FDCA. Increasing the NaOH concentration facilitated the further oxidation of HMFCA into FDCA over Au, which manifested that OH− could regulate the evolution of HMF as well as the product distribution. Similarly, Strasser and Vuyyuru evaluated the activity of a heterogeneous electrochemical Pt catalyst for HMF oxidation [23], and they observed that the oxidation of the hydroxyl group of HMF was easy at lower pH (≤7) but served as the rate-determining step at higher pH (≤13). Beyond the role in the neutralization of the produced FDCA which otherwise will strongly adsorb on the metallic surface and thus arouse the deactivation, bases facilitate the hydration of –CHO group to form geminal diol intermediate for further oxidative dehydrogenation to the final –COOH. By detailedly analyzed the influence of base in Pt/C mediated HMF oxidation, Rass et al. [24] pointed out that the higher strength of bases led to a higher catalytic performance in moderately basic aqueous solutions. When choosing NaOH as a base with high concentration, the reaction solution became heavily colored from the beginning, suggesting that HMF suffered from severe degradation. The blank experiments indicated that the degradation of HMF in basic solution was almost inevitable even using the moderate Na2CO3. The degradation and selective oxidation of HMF become competitive and affect the yield of the desired product. Most of the noble metal catalysts can rapidly convert HMF to the oxidized intermediates due to their high activity to surpass the degradation to achieve a high FDCA yield; in addition, the catalytic reaction over noble metal catalysts often operated at a lower temperature and in a shorter time course, further mitigating the adverse effects of HMF degradation. However, for the otherwise catalysts with lower activity, such as cheap metals, carbon-based catalysts, as well as some non-optimized noble metal catalysts, strong alkaline will result in a more serious degradation due to the elevated temperature and extended time. Thus, the relatively weaker bases (NaHCO3, Na2CO3) were widely employed in these systems. Fig. 2 (a) further demonstrates that the choices preference of soluble bases in the HMF oxidation reactions listed in Tables 1–3 were closely correlated with reaction time and temperature, although determined primarily by the activity of catalysts. The structural parameters of catalysts like particle size, exposed crystal planes, and metal-support interaction have obvious effects on the reaction turnover frequency [25–32]. Siyo et al. [25] reported that the Pd nanoparticles (NPs) with a mean diameter of 1.8 nm in an alkaline aqueous solution (T = 90 °C, p O2 = 0.1 MPa) afforded up to 90% yield of FDCA. The influence of supports on the aerobic oxidation of HMF into FDCA was also studied [26]. Deposited the above 1.8 nm Pd NPs on different metal oxides (TiO2, γ-Al2O3, KF/Al2O3, and ZrO2/La2O3), the Pd/ZrO2/La2O3 catalyst showed the best catalytic performance (>90% yield of FDCA) and stability with the addition of 2 equivalents(equiv.) of NaHCO3. Liu et al. [27] studied the facet effect of single-crystalline Pd nanocrystals through experimental and theoretical approaches and pointed out that the catalytic performance was notably controlled by the particle size and exposed facet of Pd nanocrystals. The (111)-faceted Pd nanooctahedrons (Pd-NOs) were more active than (100)-faceted nanocubes (Pd-NCs) especially in the conversion of HMF to HMFCA and FFCA. However, the situation is different for the single-crystalline Pt nanocrystals with particle size of sub-10 nm. Yu et al. [28] found that Pt-NCs enclosed by the (100) facets exhibited higher catalytic activity compared with Pt-NOs enclosed by the (111) facets and Pt nanospheres (Pt-NSs), mainly due to the fact that •OH created on Pt(100) facet is more active for the dehydrogenation of HMFCA to form FFCA compared with the •O2 generated on Pt (111) facet. Recently, Jiang et al. [29] found that the activity in the productivity of FDCA by the atomic Pd catalyst supported on MnO2 was over twice that of its Pd nanoparticle counterpart. The experimental and theoretical results revealed that the high dispersion of atomic Pd maximized the metal-support interactions and tuned the electronic properties of active sites, thus enhancing their binding affinity to the HMF molecules. Our group also successfully developed highly porous nitrogen- and phosphorus-codoped graphene sheets (HPGS) supported Pd catalysts under mild conditions. The structure–activity correlation demonstrated that the heteroatoms doped support will enhance the fraction of surface Pd2+ species, which plays a crucial role in reducing of the activation energies of both HMF conversion and FDCA formation [30]. Especially, the apparent activation energy (E a) of FDCA formation exhibited a linear dependency on the fraction of surface Pd2+ (PdII, %), which can be quantitatively described by the equation E a,FDCA = 80.69–0.23 × PdII. This finding provided a new strategy to develop a highly active catalyst by regulating the interaction between the active component and support toward the energy-saving production of FDCA (Fig. 3 ). In view of the high cost of Au, Pd and Pt, researchers began to employ the less expensive Ru as the active phase for HMF oxidation. Liu et al. [33] compared the performances of activated carbon-supported Ru (Ru/C), Pt (Pt/C), Pd (Pd/C) catalysts and metal oxides-supported Ru catalysts (Ru/ZrO2, Ru/TiO2, Ru/Al2O3), revealing that Ru/C was far superior to the others with much higher FDCA selectivity and carbon balance. The authors also found that the strong basicity of NaOH and Na2CO3 facilities the formation of humins via HMF ring-opening and polymerization reactions. Although Mg(OH)2 has low solubility in water (K sp = 1.5 × 1011) to form a suspension, the dissociation of the small amount of its dissolved part is sufficient to act an outstanding basic additive to provide the best performance. Kerdi et al. [34] claimed that Ru nanoparticles supported on nitrogen-containing carbons could catalyze HMF oxidation with a complete conversion and a 93% yield of FDCA in the aqueous NaHCO3. The results highlighted that oxygen-functionalized and amine-functionalized catalyst surface exhibited a detrimental impact on the reaction rate. To reduce the catalyst costs, cheap metals were often chosen to lower the proportion of noble metal in alloys or serve as cocatalysts or promoters [35]. In 1993, Verdeguer et al. [36] reported that FDCA yield increased from 81% to 99% after merging Pb into Pt/C catalyst. Albonetti et al. demonstrated that the catalytic performance of TiO2 supported Au catalyst was remarkably increased at the presence of Cu, which by itself was not active in the HMF oxidation. The strong effect of Au/Cu atomic ratio in the alloyed bimetallic nanoparticles was observed on catalytic activity and reusability. With the optimum 1.5 wt% total metal loading, the catalyst with Au/Cu ratio of 3 presented the best catalytic activity, while the bimetallic system with Au/Cu ratio of 1 showing the highest level of reusability [35]. Rass et al. exploited non-noble metal Bi as a promoter to prepare Pt-Bi/TiO2 and Pt-Bi/C catalysts for deep oxidation of HMF to FDCA with > 99% yield using NaHCO3 and NaCO3 at elevated temperatures [24,37]. A Bi/Pt molar ratio of ca. 0.2 accelerated the reaction and partially prevented the catalyst deactivation upon recycling operations. Yang et al. [38] also found that the Bi doping could thoroughly change the catalytic behavior of Pt/CeO2 in HMF oxidation. The Bi-doped CeO2 accelerated the oxygen reduction process due to the presence of abundant oxygen vacancies and the cleavage of the peroxide intermediate promoted by bismuth. The unique function was well incorporated with the activity of Pt during the catalytic oxidation cycle, endowing the Pt/Ce0.8Bi0.2O2-δ catalyst with the best performance yielding 98% of FDCA within 30 min at room temperature. Heterogeneous catalysis seems to be more favorable than homogenous catalysis due to the easy separation of the catalyst from the reaction suspension system and hence good recyclability of the catalyst. The product solution is filtered or centrifuged for catalyst separation, and the isolated catalyst is washed with dilute alkali solution and water in sequence and reused for the following run. However, the filtration and centrifugation operations still cause inevitable loss and the waste of rare metal resources as well as more consumption of energy, while the combination with magnetic nanostructures greatly improves the recovering efficiency. Zhang and co-workers [39–41] prepared a series of novel magnetic catalysts using Pd and Fe (γ-Fe2O3@HAP-Pd, C-Fe3O4-Pd, and Pd/C@Fe3O4) for the aerobic oxidation of HMF in water with 0.5 equivalent of a weak base under mild reaction conditions. The highest yield of FDCA reached 93% and the external magnet facilitated the separating of catalyst particles to keep the activity after the fifth run. The purpose of the combination of magnetic Fe3O4 and hydrophilia carbon surface is to improve the separation and recovery of the catalyst (Fig. 4 ). Zhou et al. [42] adopted the analogous strategy to develop a novel Pt nanocatalyst supported on Fe3O4 decorated with reduced graphene oxide (Pt/Fe3O4/rGO). The results highlighted that the introduction of Fe3O4 could increase the dispersion, thus promote the utilization and the catalytic activity of Pt. The activation of –OH and –CHO groups was enhanced at the Pt/Fe3O4 interface, providing a twice higher reaction rate as that of Fe3O4-free catalyst. After five times of magnetic recycle, Pt/Fe3O4/rGO remained relatively stable with Pt loading decreasing from 5.0 wt% to 4.9 wt% and Fe content decreasing from 22.1 wt% to 20.6 wt% as well as a slight deterioration in catalytic performance (7% HMF conversion and 19% FDCA selectivity). Beyond magnetic Fe3O4, by partially replacing Fe(III) in spinel-phase ZnFe2O4 by Ru(III), Qi et al. [43] synthesized a series of trimetallic catalysts with soft magnetic characteristics via a simple alkali-coprecipitation method, albeit the catalytic performance in aqueous phase needed to be improved. Apart from precious metal catalysts, the concept of magnetic separation was expanded to transition metal oxide and immobilized enzyme for the oxidation of HMF, such as magnetic MnFe2O4 catalyst [44] and laccase catalyst [45], respectively. Table 1 summarizes the catalytic performance of HMF oxidation over single noble metal catalysts. 2.1.2 Dual noble metal catalysts Owing to the instability of single noble metal catalysts, the active metal atoms are easy to leach out to the reaction mixture and thus the deactivation of the catalyst is usually unavoided, especially with the presence of strong acid or base. In order to enhance the recyclable stability and activity of the single noble metal catalyst in the HMF oxidation reaction to produce FDCA, some researchers have introduced secondary metal as an additive to adjust the electronic properties of the active centers and to form a smaller particle size of the catalyst. Compared to monometallic catalysts, the physical and chemical properties of bi- and multi-metallic catalysts may be tuned efficiently by varying the composition, crystalline state, alloying degree, and grain boundary. Numerous bimetallic catalysts based on mixing or alloying Au or Pt with a second non-noble metal were reported with improved catalytic efficiency and stability [24,35,37,38,55]. However, the active sites of these catalysts are relatively too single to meet higher requirements, and it is possible to further improve the catalytic performance by incorporating another active noble metal to strengthen the synergistic effect or accelerate the different fundamental steps. The rational design of multi-component noble metals can indeed combine the advantages of different components and thus harvest much higher efficiency than that obtained by simply mixing the two single noble metal catalysts. As examples of Pt-M [56] and Ru-M (M = noble metal) catalysts are rarely reported in FDCA production, this section focuses on the discussion of Au-Pd catalyst systems. In 2013, Villa et al. [56] showed that the modification of Au/C catalyst with Pd or Pt generated excellent catalytic efficiency and stability under realistic reaction conditions. AuPd catalysts performed more active than AuPt ones, achieving almost full conversion to FDCA within 2 h and 4 h, respectively, whereas Au catalyst needed 6 h to reach just 80% selectivity. Due to irreversible adsorption of intermediates or Au particle agglomeration rather than Au leaching, Au/C catalyst underwent apparent deactivation, losing 20% of activity after the fifth run. Alloying Au with Pd in an optimal 8:2 atomic ratio endowed the bimetallic catalyst with a more active and stable performance to completely convert HMF with 99% selectivity to FDCA over all five runs. In addition, the conjunction of a second metal to Au-based catalyst can affect the oxidation reaction pathways of HMF. For example, the oxidation pathway of HMF has been changed from HMFCA to DFF by the introduction of Pd to Au/CNT catalyst where Pd active sites support the oxidation of the –OH groups of HMF, and promote the further oxidation of FFCA to FDCA, which is a difficult step for Au catalysts [57]. Very recently, Liao et al. [58] engineered a Co3O4 supported catalyst with an active interface between Au-Pd alloy NPs by calcining alloy embedded ZIF-67 metal–organic frameworks for highly efficient conversion HMF to yield 95% of FDCA within 1 h. The time-course composition of reaction systems revealed that the conversions of HMF achieved equally 100% in 10 min, while the yields to HMFCA were 80% and 20% for Au@Co3O4 and Au0.5Pd@Co3O4, respectively. After 1 h reaction, 50% of HMFCA remained as the main product over Au@Co3O4 compared to the almost complete conversion of HMFCA over the Pd modified catalyst within 40 min. On the other hand, Pd@Co3O4 and Pd/C were unable to oxidize HMFCA as a reactant. The results suggested that the oxidation of HMFCA was mostly contributed to the Au species and can be promoted by adding Pd into Au NPs to reduce the activation barrier. As a structure–activity relationship, one of the key factors affecting the catalytic performance of HMF-to-FDCA was the increase in the percentage of active Au+ owing to the size effect. Detailed characterization indicated that the reduced particle size of metal NPs could be attributed to alloying Au with Pd. Albonetti et al. [59–61] synthesized bimetallic Pd-Au nanoparticles with alloy and core–shell structures and found that catalytic reactivities and reaction paths depended on preferentially exposed active phase composition (either Au or Pd atoms). Both monometallic Au and Pd NPs transformed HMF to HMFCA, while the subsequent oxidation of HMFCA to FDCA preferentially occurred on monometallic Au (12%–19% of selectivity to FDCA) or bimetallic Pd-Au catalysts (up to 85% of FDCA selectivity) rather than monometallic Pd NPs (0%–9% of selectivity to FDCA). However, catalysis on the Pd-Au catalyst calcined at 300 °C revealed a decreased selectivity to FDCA to be only 50% after the same 4 h reaction time, whereas the selectivity to HMFCA was constant to about 50% during the whole time. The author ascribed the results to the Pd migration towards the surface to form Pd layer or Pd-rich shell by de-alloying of Au and Pd upon calcination. The highly consistent behavior over bimetallic Au@Pd and Pd@Au catalysts confirmed the speculation again [59]. In particular, for the TiO2 supported catalysts, as Au content in alloys increasing, the selectivity to FDCA increased in the order of Au1Pd3 < Au1Pd1 ≪ Au3Pd1 < Au9Pd1 < Au6Pd1 [60], suggesting a synergic effect existed in the bimetallic catalysts. The distribution of reaction products was strongly affected by the Pd:Au atomic ratio due to the fact that a small quantity of Pd was adequate to significantly change the electronic properties of Au and enhance its catalytic activity. The similar synergistic effect between Pd and Au on enhancing the HMF conversion and FDCA selectivity was also validated by Qi et al., where the yield of FDCA increased to > 99% when the Pd:Au molar ratio reached 1:1 [62]. The potential-dependent electrocatalytic oxidation of HMF on supported bimetallic Au-Pd nanoparticles in alkaline media was also explored to reveal a synergistic effect of Au-Pd alloy on the highly selective formation of FDCA [63]. Deeply oxidized products (FFCA and FDCA) could be produced over bimetallic catalysts at lower potentials with respect to monometallic catalysts. Although the Au-Pd bimetallic catalysts were often reported to be highly active in oxidation of HMF into FDCA [64–66], the synergistic strategy by alloying two or more precious metals will complicate the procedure and push the cost of catalyst even higher. The catalytic performance of HMF oxidation over dual noble metal catalysts are listed in Table 2. 2.1.3 Cheap metal and carbon-based catalysts The efficient recycling of precious metals is able to suppress the capital cost of the catalytic oxidation process, but developing inexpensive transition metal and metal-free catalysts is always the ultimate goal of the biorefinery industry. The Co(OAc)2/Mn(OAc)2/HBr catalyst was firstly introduced into HMF oxidation for industrial production of terephthalic acid by Partenheimer [67,68], but the separation of catalyst and the final product is always one of the challenges in the homogeneous catalytic system. This study inspires extensive research on heterogeneous catalysis based on transition metals. During the investigation on manganese-based heterogeneous oxidation catalysis with O2 as the sole oxidant [69], Hara’s group found that the activated MnO2 catalyzes the oxidation of HMF to FDCA more efficiently than SrMnO3 in the presence of NaHCO3 as an additive [70]. Interestingly, the comparative experiment under Ar atmosphere revealed that HMF was converted into oxygenated products with almost the same reaction rate as that under O2 atmosphere. In addition, the reaction rates over MnO2 were slightly dependent on the pressure of O2, and doubled when the pressure raised from 0.1 to 1.0 MPa. The authors interpreted such phenomena to the substrate oxidation by oxygen supplied from the catalyst itself (Mars-van Krevelen mechanism). During this process, the formation of partially reduced MnO2-δ or irreversible MnOOH will affect the stability of MnO2. Thus, the crystallization is helpful to improve the structural stability of MnO2. It is well known that MnO2 has various crystal structures, which was demonstrated to be very crucial to catalytic HMF oxidation to FDCA through combined computational and experimental studies recently by the above research group [71]. Density functional theory (DFT) simulations revealed that the vacancy formation energies at the bent oxygen sites in β- and λ-MnO2 are lower than those at the planar oxygen sites in α- and γ-MnO2, suggesting the first two types are likely to be good candidates for the target reaction. Experimental studies, including the kinetic, mechanistic, and spectroscopic investigations, further demonstrated that the reaction rates of the rate-determining step (FFCA → FDCA) decrease in the order of β-MnO2 > λ-MnO2 > γ-MnO2 ≈ α-MnO2 > δ-MnO2 > ε-MnO2. So, Hara’s group confirmed that the combined theoretical and experimental approachescan provide a rational strategy to design highly effective MnO2 catalysts. In addition, the catalytic performance of the β-MnO2 can be further improved significantly by increasing its surface area [71]. Beyond crystal structure, the diverse oxidation states to form redox pairs of Mn2+/Mn3+ or Mn3+/Mn4+ also endow manganese oxides with outstanding catalytic properties. Hu et al. [72] combined the redox cycle of the Mn cations with abundant surface pores to develop a holey 2D Mn2O3 nanoflakes by the controlled heat-treatment of a Mn-based metal–organic framework (Mn-MOF). The obtained nanoflakes (M400) exhibited outstanding catalytic activity for the aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA, significantly outperforming commercial Mn2O3 and activated MnO2 as well as the above Mn-based catalysts in the aspect of reaction rates. In addition, according to the Mars-Van-Krevelen mechanism, oxidation reactions over manganese oxides rely closely upon the oxygen mobility from the external O2 to the oxide’s lattice oxygen to complete the catalytic cycle and regenerate the surface of catalyst (Fig. 5 a). Due to its high oxygen storage capacity, CeO2 was employed by Wang et al. to promote the lattice oxygen transfer from Ce oxide to Mn oxide to enhance the catalytic activity and selectivity [73]. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments revealed that the reduction temperature decreased gradually with the increase of Ce proportion, verifying that the oxygen mobility was significantly improved due to the addition of Ce oxides. This study also pointed out the high concentrations of Mn4+ and Ce3+ on the MnO x -CeO2 surface play a key role as active sites for the HMF oxidation. Superior oxygen mobility and various oxidation states are widely accepted to elucidate the remarkable performance of multitudinous Mn-based composites, such as Co-Mn-0.25 [74], MnCo2O4 [75], and Mn-Fe mixed oxide [76]. Yu et al. [77] further proposed that active M3+O(-Mn4+)2 clusters in (Fe, Co, Ni)-doped MnO x catalysts were the principal active sites for the aerobic oxidation of HMF (Fig. 5b). This work also provided a universal mechanism based on electron transfer inside the catalytically active sites for binary [78] and ternary metal oxides [79]. Mn-free catalysts were also explored in the past few years. Yang et al. [55] reported 97% of HMF conversion was reached in 20 min at 65 °C and 1 MPa O2 over Ce1- x Bi x O2- δ (0.08 ≤ x ≤ 0.5), which was attributed to the enhanced O2 activation by Bi doping. However, only a small amount of FDCA formed with an 8% yield after reaction for 1 h, in spite of the reaction rate for FDCA superior to most of Mn-based catalysts. Li et al. [80] fabricated three CuO/Al2O3 catalysts with smooth, porous and needle-like fiber morphologies for aerobic oxidation of HMF in relatively low temperature (50 °C), in which needle-like CuO/Al2O3 exhibiting active and stable properties to achieve 98.6% yield of FDCA. The superior performance was attributed to the unique needle-like mullite structure and uniformly distributed CuO as active site. Zhang et al. [81] developed a highly active photocatalyst for HMF oxidation by immobilizing cobalt thioporphyrazine (CoPz) on graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) to form CoPz/g-C3N4. Interesting, pure CoPz and CoPz/g-C3N4 catalysts were active to some extent in dark condition to show the same FDCA yield of 90% with the HMF conversions of 11.5% and 17.5%, respectively. CoPz was recognized as the active sites, whereas g-C3N4 was inactive for FDCA formation, whether there was light irradiation or not. Apart from the improved dispersion of CoPz by adding hydrophobic g-C3N4 support to provide more CoPz sites accessible to the polar substrate of HMF, the strong interaction between the CoPz and g-C3N4 resulted in a higher electronic cloud density in the CoPz/g-C3N4 than that in pure CoPz, and thus led to a much higher catalytic activity under the same conditions. Su et al. [82] compared the catalytic performance of Mo- and W-based heteropoly acids for HMF oxidation by H2O2 at 100 °C for 2 h. Quaternary ammonium dectungstate embraced an equal number of single epoxy groups and double epoxy groups in the presence of H2O2. The high steric hindrance of quaternary ammonium inhibited the HMFCA oxidation into FDCA since the double epoxy groups as the active sites were competitively adsorbed by a quaternary ammonium. However, three quarters of the double epoxy group in quaternary ammonium octamolybdate were free from quaternary ammonium, which endowed the Mo-based catalyst a superior activity to FDCA. Leaching or leakage of metal ions from metal-based catalysts resulted in increased production cost and difficult product purification. Therefore, the development of efficient metal-free catalysts for the aerobic oxidation of HMF is appropriate for great significance. Nguyen and co-workers [83] reported the oxidation of HMF to FDCA using the zeolitic-imidazole framework (ZIF-8) derived nitrogen-doped nanoporous carbon (NNC) as the catalyst. Graphitic N (N-Q) in these NNC catalysts was recognized as the catalytic active sites due to the fact that the FDCA yield was proportional to the amount of N-Q, while there was no relationship between the activity and the amount of pyridinic-N or pyrrolic-N species. A similar role of N-Q was also reported in our previous work on oxidative dehydrogenation of propane by nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes [84]. The full conversion of HMF was achieved within 4 h at 80 °C and ambient pressure when the yield of FDCA increased to a maximum of 80% with the reaction time. The reaction pathway on the doped carbon catalyst would be HMF-HMFCA-FFCA-FDCA due to the absence of DFF intermediate. The FFCA-FDCA step was the rate-determining step and the consumption of HMFCA or FFCA was relatively slow compared to HMF. Varma et al. [85] developed a porous nitrogen-enriched carbon nitride catalyst (PCN x ), via carbonization of marine waste originated from chitosan, for the aerial oxidation of HMF to FDCA under mild reaction conditions. The oxidation of HMF over PCN x was accomplished in 83% FDCA yield under ambient pressure at 70 °C. The PCN x catalyst exhibited good recyclability without any significant loss in its activity and structure for five runs. On account of the widely reported effect of graphitic nitrogen on oxygen activation in gaseous and liquid reactions, this study also compared nitrogen-doped graphene and graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4), obtaining only 5% and 15% yield of FDCA in the same conditions, respectively. Therefore, the conclusions that graphitic nitrogen in PCN x activates O2 and is critical to the aerobic oxidation of alcohols need more details to support. Anyway, green metal-free catalysts will play a more prominent role in the catalytic oxidation of biomass or other organic compounds if the number of active centers with a precise molecular structure could be greatly enhanced. The catalytic performance of HMF oxidation into FDCA over cheap metal and carbon-based catalysts are listed in Table 3. 2.2 Solid alkali system 2.2.1 Hydrotalcite and layered double hydroxide The excess use of homogeneous bases is likely to cause equipment corrosion during the reaction and large energy consumption in the product isolation procedure, and thus a variety of recoverable solid bases have attracted increasing attention. Hydrotalcite (HT), one of the layered double hydroxides (LDHs) consisting of brucite-like layers with abundant –OH groups on the surface, emerged as a rising-star solid base material for dispersing metal NPs to prevent aggregation. However, HT is not stable enough at low values of pH (pH < 9.0) [86], which can be readily etched and neutralized by acidic reagents. Davis et al. [87] certified that the employment of HT to replace NaOH in the HMF reaction medium benefited the production of FDCA (>99% yield) over Au/TiO2, but stoichiometrical consumption of magnesium ions triggered the severe leaching of HT by forming soluble salts of the product diacid due to the high acidity of FDCA (pK a = 2.28 ± 0.10) [88]. In order to slow the Mg dissolution, an excess HT added to the reaction to reach a higher pH throughout the reaction [87]. Similar to the liquid alkali oxidation, the final product diacid can also isolate from the product solution by filtering or centrifugation following by acidification. However, the separation of catalyst and the rest HT from each other raise additional difficulties if the HT is not completely consumed. Despite the consumption, Mg-Al HT can also be used as the additive to the Ru/AC catalyst to afford high efficient oxidation of HMF to FDCA, being superior to the bases like MgO, Ca(OH)2, K2CO3 and NaOH on the basis of its proper strength of basicity [89,90]. Gupta et al. [91] directly employed HT as a basic support of gold nanoparticles to efficiently catalyze the HMF-FDCA reaction using molecular oxygen in water at 95 °C, where the basicity of HT assisted the conversion of aldehydes into hemiacetals as well the production of gold alcoholate species via gold hydride shift from HMFCA. Ardemani et al. [92] subsequently demonstrated that the moderate strength base sites of hydrotalcites and the high fraction of exposed gold atoms synergically contributed to selective cascade oxidation of aldehyde and alcohol (Fig. 6 ). Gorbanev et al. [93,94] observed that ruthenium hydroxide supported on HT and other metal oxides could afford FDCA with the highest yield of ~ 100% under optimized condition. However, ICP analysis confirmed that magnesium-based HT and oxide supports dissolved partially to leach Mg ions during the catalytic reaction. In 2016, basicity-tuned HT-supported Pd catalysts for the highly efficient oxidation of HMF to FDCA in aqueous solutions were reported [95]. The FDCA yield higher than 99.9% was achieved under mild conditions when the Mg/Al molar ratio of HT was 5, which could be attributed to the moderate basicity of the Mg-Al-CO3 hydrotalcite and the sufficient –OH groups on the surface. Importantly, these catalysts could be recycled at least five times without apparent loss in the reaction reactivity. Monometallic and bimetallic Pt catalysts supported on HT were also systematically studied to understand the influence of metal species on catalytic activity [96,97]. Ebitani et al. demonstrated that the type of metals employed and their ratio of the combination were closely related to the activity of the catalysts, following the order of PdPt-PVP/HT > Pt-PVP/HT > AuPd-PVP/HT > Pd-PVP/HT > AuPt-PVP/HT > Au-PVP/HT. Among these catalysts, the bimetallic Pd20Pt80-PVP/HT owned the highest activity to produce FDCA (>99% yield) without the addition of a soluble base [96]. Interestingly, beyond the synergistic effect between Au and Pd supported on HT [57] and CaMgAl-LDH [98], Fang and his co-workers [99,100] revealed the synergy between two components in HT-activated carbon composite (HT-AC) support. As comparing to Au/HT and Au/AC catalysts, the co-presence of HT and activated carbon (AC) in the support of Au/HT-AC with the optimal mass ratio (2:1) would significantly enhance the catalytic activity and stability. 2.2.2 Other basic supports or additives In addition to HT and LDH, some novel basic supports have been reported recently. Cho et al. [101] investigated a series of basic metal oxide supported Ru catalysts and found the catalytic activity for HMF oxidation was related primarily to the basicity of support in the order of MgAlO > MgO > ZrO2 > CeO2 ≫ La2O3. Unexpectedly, the most active MgAlO support was not stable under the catalytic condition and seriously dissolved due to the poor resistance to the acidic nature of the produced FDCA. However, Ru/MgO, a bit less active than Ru/MgAlO, afforded a 100% conversion of HMF with greater than 90% yield of FDCA at 160 °C in 4 h and could be reused 5 cycles without a significant loss in activity. Wang et al. [102] designed a novel Pt/C-O-Mg catalyst by encapsulating MgO particles in carbon and then loading platinum on the carbon surface. The Pt/C-O-Mg catalyst exhibited satisfactory selectivity and stability due to the formation of C-O-Mg bond with the capability to create stable basic sites. Under the optimal conditions (110 °C, 1.0 MPa O2), FDCA yield over this catalyst reached 97% and stabilized at around 95% with little deactivation after ten cycles. N-doped carbon supported Pt catalyst was also tested by this research group [103]. CO2-TPD revealed that the doped nitrogen introduced a new moderate strength basic site on the carbon surface. The relationship between the catalytic activity and the relative abundance of nitrogen species suggested that the pyridine-type nitrogen species coordinated the HMF oxidation into FDCA. Moreover, increase of nitrogen content in carbon support has a promotion effect on catalytic activity by more basic sites and higher alkalinity. Li et al. [104] developed nitrogen-doped-carbon-decorated CeO2 (NC-CeO2) as a basic support to fabricate Pt/NC-CeO2 catalyst, exhibiting exceptional catalytic efficiency superior to the Pt catalysts supported on CeO2 and g-C3N4 with an almost 100% FDCA yield at 110 °C for 8 h (or 150 °C for 4 h) in free of any soluble base. CO2-TPD demonstrated that the introduction of the electron-rich nitrogen atoms can strengthen the surface basicity, particularly a small amount of the strong Lewis base sites (SLB) on Pt/NC-CeO2, which played an important role in improving the oxidation of –OH of HMF. Recently, nanosized NiO was also recognized to be an effective basic support to promote the HMF conversion. Albonetti et al. [105] interpreted the synergistic effect between AuPd alloy and NiO as the electronic and geometrical properties of AuPd metal were tuned by the NiO support, thereby affecting the substrate binding at the metal/support interface. Besides the above inorganic base support, some nitrogen-containing organic materials were applied as basic support for heterogeneous catalysts due to their sufficient thermal stability and robust structure, as well as insoluble in most conventional solvents, acids, and bases. Artz et al. [20] reported that Ru clusters supported on covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs) provided a superior FDCA yield (91%) at 140 °C and 2 MPa of synthetic air without additional base. It was clarified that the hydrophilic carrier with a nitrogen content of 10.4% allowed the efficient oxidation of HMF to FDCA under the aqueous-phase conditions without any alkali additives. Saha et al. [6] introduced porphyrin-based porous organic polymer to loading Fe catalyst (FeIII-POP-1) for the oxidation reaction to acquire a yield of FDCA up to 79% in 10 h under milder conditions. EPR spectra analysis of the recovered catalyst and the contrast experiment using homogeneous FeIII–porphyrin complex as catalyst revealed that, the high surface area and Fe3+ as active sites of the FeIII-POP-1 catalyst played a vital role for HMF oxidation. The Fe(III) mediated HMF oxidation was believed to undergo a radical chain mechanism involving a classical Fenton-type reaction and the formation of peroxyl radicals via thermal autoxidation. Even more significantly, this catalytic system did not need the use of soluble base and precious metal to afford full HMF conversion and a high FDCA yield, further inspiring the development of cheap and efficient catalysts for sustainable chemistry. Table 4 summarizes the catalytic performance of HMF oxidation using solid base system. 2.3 Base-free system Generally, the oxidation of HMF in the basic environments is kinetically favorable and offers higher FDCA productivity, as seen in Fig. 2(b). However, the neutralization of the product solution and acidification of salt to diacid are essential and easy to produce wastes. Additionally, solid base supports can circumvent the requirement for liquid alkali additives for the oxidation of HMF, but the acidic nature of the generated FDCA has the potential to etch basic support and raise concerns on catalyst stability. Nevertheless, several heterogeneous catalysts under base-free conditions are challenging the previous base-participated researches, and they offer us hope to explore a completely sustainable process for FDCA production. In particular, noble metals owing to their outstanding role in the activation of oxygen show good catalytic ability in oxidizing –OH and –CHO groups to form corresponding aldehydes and acids. Combined with the intrinsical instability of HMF, the selective transformation to FDCA on noble metal become feasible even without the assistance of alkali additives. The base-free aerobic oxidation often follows a DFF-mediated pathway and the mechanism presented in Fig. 14, different from the situation using alkaline medium or solid base [3]. Overall, the base-free method is more simplified and environmental-friendly, despite the lower concentration of the feedstock and higher reaction temperatures are needed to drive the system to obtain moderate productivity of FDCA compared to the oxidations in alkaline medium (Fig. 2b). For the catalyst, the acidic-basic and adsorption–desorption properties of support have significant impacts on the catalytic behavior. Thanks to their extraordinary properties, such as high surface area, hierarchically porous structure, versatile surface chemistry, superior mechanical stability, as well as outstanding thermal and electrical conductivity, carbon materials proved to be outstanding support for the metal catalysts or used as high-performance catalyst directly [106,107]. Sharma et al. [108] found the HNO3-refluxed carbon nanotube (CNT) enabled 86.5% HMF to convert totally into FFCA in base-free water, without any detectable FDCA, DFF, and other species, suggesting the catalytic ability of the functionalized CNT itself. After supported metals (Pt, Pd, Ru, Co, and Ni), the noble metal-loaded CNT catalysts showed high selectivity towards FDCA in the order of Pt/CNT > Pd/CNT > Ru/CNT, while the non-noble metal catalysts were more selective towards DFF. Wang and co-workers [57,97] previously showed that functionalized CNT supported Pt nanoparticles and Au-Pd alloy are able to catalyze the aerobic oxidation of HMF into FDCA with a high efficiency in water without any bases. The carboxyl groups on CNT surfaces pretreated by HNO3 were unfavorable for the conversion of HMF to FDCA, whereas the carbonyl/quinone and/or phenol groups on CNT surfaces pretreated by H2O2 essentially enhanced the FDCA yield. This reaction turnover is quite similar to the previous work on the carbon-catalyzed selective oxidation of acrolein to acrylic acid by Frank et al., which revealed the determining role of carbonyl/quinone groups for oxygen insertion in acrolein molecules by reaction kinetics and in-situ XPS characterization [109]. Apart from CNT, graphene oxide (GO), reduced graphene oxide (rGO) [42], carbon nanofiber (CNF), activated carbon (AC) [90] and carbon black [110] were also applicable to support noble metal nanoparticles to catalyze this reaction to some extent, while SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, and CeO2 supported catalysts were inactive under the base-free condition in Wang’s system [57,97]. However, these oxides were often reported to support catalyst to realize remarkable activity for FDCA production [111,112]. For instance, Pt catalyst supported on low surface area ZrO2 using atomic layer deposition (ALD) showed a high activity close to the aforementioned Pt/CNT catalyst in terms of turnover frequency (TOF) under similar conditions, i.e., 6.85 h−1 vs. 7.00 h−1. This was mainly ascribed to the high Pt dispersion and uniform active sites as well as the desirable adsorption ability of the reactant/intermediates achieved by ALD technique [113,114]. Similar strategy for increasing dispersion was employed by Pichler et al. [115] to establish a high-surface-area ZrO2 supported Ru catalyst to realize a full conversion of HMF with 97% yield of FDCA, suggesting once again the influence of support properties derived from different synthesis method on metal particle size and consequent catalytic activity. Prompted by the diverse chemical states and specific oxidative properties, as discussed in 2.1.3 section, Mn-containing catalysts exhibit remarkable catalytic performance for HMF oxidation even without the aid of base additives. Kim et al. [116] developed a new class of Mn-Co-O spinel supported Ru catalysts with a pronounced yield of FDCA (99.1%) and good recyclability in a pure water solvent, and they attributed the reason to the coexistence of Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites. Actually, such a solid support can be seen as a heterogeneous replica of homogeneous Co(OAc)2/Mn(OAc)2/HBr for HMF oxidation, likely going through a similar redox cascade [117]. Mn-Ce mixed oxides-supported Ru NPs (Ru/Mn X Ce1O Y ) were firstly employed by Gao et al. [118] as a base-free catalyst for HMF oxidation, undergoing a DFF-intermediated reaction route to yield the final product FDCA. Ru0 species were believed to adsorb and activate HMF, while the mixed oxides- support facilitated the adsorption, dissociation, and mobility of oxygen (Fig. 7 ). The authors announced that the strong metal-support interaction together with the synergy between Ce and Mn oxides highly contributed to the superior performance of Ru/Mn6Ce1O Y , exhibiting a high catalytic activity with 95% FDCA yield (TOF = 5.3 h−1) and excellent stability after 8 runs. Taking the strong redox properties of MnO2 and CuO into consideration, Ventura et al. [119] directly utilized quaternary CuO·MnO2·CeO2 oxide as a catalyst to convert HMF into FDCA under aqueous phase with O2 as oxidant, demonstrating the independence of external bases and precious metals to maintain a considerable activity with high stability after 12 runs. Although the yield of product was limited at 70.8% due to the deposition of humins or organics on the catalyst, supplementing fresh catalyst or decarbonizing spent catalyst could eliminate the limitation to achieve much higher FDCA yield up to 98.7%. Simple calcination at 550 °C could recover the catalytic activity by not only excluding carbon deposit but also repairing the transient deactivation derived from Cu2+ reduction to Cu0 rather than leaching. This inspires us for more efforts in developing appropriate catalyst to resist carbon deposition. More importantly, the acidic/basic properties of the mixed oxides can be moderated by varying the calcination temperature, showing the possibility to regulate the distribution of products in pure water as solution [120–122]. The similar tunable acidic-basic properties also exist in hydroxyapatite (HAP) materials and rely critically on its Ca/P ratio, showing both the acidic and basic characteristics when the Ca/P ratio among 1.50 to 1.67. For the base-free aerobic catalysis on Ru/HAP, besides the critical role of Ru, the basic sites of support acted to cleave the O–H bond of HMF to form a Ru-alkoxide intermediate and promote the subsequent oxidation of –CHO to –COOH, while the acidic sites of support involved in oxidizing the Ru hydride to generate a H2O molecule [123]. Adoption of pure water as a solvent without any basic or acidic additives has been an important direction for this reaction. However, the limitations still exist to some extent in base-free system, such as unsatisfactory activity of catalysts, leaching of active components by the strong acidity of product, side reactions under the harsh reaction conditions, coverage of catalytic sites by FDCA deposition, as well as the low productivity and sustainability by batch reaction. Performing base-free aerobic oxidation in continuous mode will fix some of the shortcomings. In 2010, Lilga et al. [124] first reported HMF oxidation in a bench-scale flow reactor with aqueous HMF feed under basic, neutral, and acidic conditions. A 3/8-inch stainless-steel tube heated in a tube furnace was employed as a fixed-bed reactor to screen catalysts and operating conditions. As a result, during the two-week neutral continuous-flow reaction, the aerial oxidation over 5% Pt/ZrO2 catalysts steadily afforded full HMF conversion with FDCA yield of up to 98% at 100 °C with a 0.5 wt% HMF feed (liquid hourly space velocity = 3 h−1), in spite of inhibition occurring by precipitate. Recently, Liguori et al. [125] exploited a continuous-flow production of FDCA in neat water using Pt nanoparticles immobilized on sulfonated DOWEX 50WX2-100 cation-exchange resin (Pt@Dowex-Na) as a catalyst, realizing productivity of 1.74 mmol gcat -1h−1 in 99% yield at 120 °C and 0.77 MPa O2 with 303 s residence time. The home-made continuous-flow system, composing mainly of a catalyst loaded glass tube reactor (I.D = 3 mm, L = 50 mm) and a controlled feeding apparatus, could afford a space–time-yield of 46 gFDCA L−1 h−1 in 99% purity after water withdrawal (Fig. 8 ). Although there are few reports so far, base-free continuous-flow production of FDCA is of great significance for developing more sustainable technology for biomass conversion and utilization. Table 5 summarizes the catalytic performance of HMF oxidation into FDCA in base-free systems. 3 Electrochemical oxidation of HMF Electrochemical catalysis has been considered as an alternative to the thermocatalysis, employing the electrode potential rather than chemical potential as the main driving force. Beyond the regulation of substrates concentration and reaction temperature or pressure in the traditional heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysis, the management of electrochemical reaction parameters realizes more accurately and conveniently by controlling the electrode potential and circuit current [126,127]. In addition, compared to the aerobic thermocatalysis, electrooxidation is a promising technology with many significant characteristics, such as extensive substrate tolerance, mild reaction conditions, low energy dissipation, high atom economy, as well as superior safety (no additional oxygen is required). In the past few decades, the electrocatalytic oxidation had made considerable progress in the fields of organic synthesis [128], pollutant degradation [129], and energy conversion [130]. To our knowledge, the first study on electrolysis of HMF was reported by Kawana et al. in 1983 [131], while electrooxidation of HMF into FDCA was first reported by Grabowski et al. in 1991 [132]. However, this research field had been scarcely progressed in the following score years since then, possibly due to the indifference of biomass by the academic and industry researchers. Until recent years, HMF electrooxidation has drawn growing attention, involving the design of electrocatalyst, coupling of reactions and the possible pathway. 3.1 Electrochemical oxidation by supported noble metal catalysts Similar to most of the heterogeneous catalysis, the electrocatalytic process often involves a surface reaction process at the interface between the active electrode and electrified electrolyte. Therefore, some thermochemically active catalysts, such as precious metals and their corresponding supported catalysts, have been proved to be electrochemically active in the same or similar reaction. In 2012, Strasser and Vuyyuru employed pure Pt foil as a working electrode for HMF oxidation in a NaOH-NaClO4 aqueous solution (pH = 10). The electrochemical activation of water in anode resulted in the in-situ generation of reactive oxygenated species and thus eliminated the need of molecular oxygen to oxidize HMF. The electrocatalytic oxidation of HMF was found very selective to form 18% yield of DFF with 70% conversion of HMF within 12 h, showing a quite different product distribution from that of heterogeneous process catalyzed by Pt/C in the same pH environment [23]. Zhou et al. [42] recently found the oxidation peak potentials of –OH and –CHO of HMF on both Pt/Fe3O4/rGO and Pt/rGO catalysts were centered at 0.5 and 0.9 V vs Ag/AgCl, respectively. By using furfuryl alcohol and furfural as simplified substrates, the further electro-oxidation revealed that the oxidation peak potential for the first substrate (0.85 V) was lower than the second substrate (0.92 V), demonstrating that the oxidation of −OH to −CHO is prior than that of −CHO to –COOH in neutral K2SO4 electrolyte. In addition, the intermediate products were detected to be DFF and FFCA after reaction in a neutral electrolyte, while only HMFCA could be detected when using 0.1 M KOH as an electrolyte. On the other hand, in 2014, Li and co-workers [63] reported the product distribution of HMF oxidation in the anion-exchange membrane electrolysis flow cell, was highly dependent on the electrode potential and catalyst surface composition. On Au/C catalyst, the oxidation of –CHO was greatly favored over oxidation of –OH to generate HMFCA, while higher electrode potentials were required for further oxidation of the –OH to yield the final FDCA. However, for the Pd/C catalyst, HMF oxidation followed two competitive routes to form FDCA and the pathway relied on the electrode potential. Furthermore, at the low potential region, oxidation of –CHO over Pd/C was much slower than that over Au/C, but was greatly enhanced by increasing potentials or alloying with Au. The Pd–Au bimetallic catalysts (Pd2Au1/C and Pd1Au2/C) achieved much higher FDCA yield at lower potentials than the two monometallic catalysts. This observation provided promising strategies to adjust the reaction pathway and depth of HMF electrochemical oxidation by altering the surface composition of catalyst and regulating the applied potential. 3.2 Electrochemical oxidation by transition metal catalysts Driven by the electrochemical potential, more and more innovative and cheap catalysts developed from earth-abundant transition metals, such as Ni2P [133], CoP [134], Ni2S3 [135], porous Ni [136], Ni x B [137], CoB [138], NiB x [139], NiCo2O4 [140,141], VN [142], Ni3N@C [143], Ni/Co/Fe oxyhydroxides [144], Ni/NiOOH [145], nanocrystalline Cu foam [146], CuNi(OH)2/C [147], NiSe@NiO x [148], NiFe-LDH [127], and Cu x S@NiCo-LDH [149], were reported to be more efficient than noble metal catalysts, reversing the situation that the precious metal catalysts are more active and popular than the transition metal catalysts in HMF thermocatalytic oxidation. Grabowski et al. [132] firstly reported the HMF electrooxidation into FDCA on NiOOH anode, realizing 71% FDCA yield with 84% faradaic efficiency (FE) in a divided H-shape electrolyzer with 1 M NaOH aqueous electrolyte. By applying the similar Ni/NiOOH foam as electrodes, Latsuzbaia et al. [145] successfully realized the continuous production of FDCA from HMF in an industrial type plate-and-frame electrolyzer with integrated product separation system for the first time (Fig. 9 ). Although the continuous HMF oxidation was performed in two steps, an unprecedented FDCA separation yield of up to 95% was obtained within the bench-scale setup [145]. Also in 2018, Han and co-workers [140] observed the significant improvement in the catalytic kinetics by introducing Co into electrocatalysts, as well as the synergetic effect of Ni and Co species in charge transfer kinetics. With the optimal doping level, the hydrothermal grown NiCo2O4 nanowires on Ni foam required only 1.55 V vs. RHE to maintain the maximum oxidation of HMF and the minimum water oxidation. By passing the stoichiometric amount of charge (35C), NiCo2O4 nanowires exhibited the best performance of up to 90% FDCA yield with 99% FE, and preserved robust structural stability after five catalytic cycles. Further XPS and XANEX analysis by Kang et al. [141] revealed that the reason for the increased HMF oxidation efficiency of NiCo2O4 was the higher portion of reduced Co3+ to Co2+ under applied potential in NiCo2O4 electrode than Co3O4 electrode. In view of the actual catalytically active species of transition metal-based electrocatalysts are most likely oxyhydroxide phases in an alkaline electrolyte, the intrinsic catalytic properties of oxyhydroxides for HMF oxidation is a pressing topic to investigate systematically. Recently, Chio et al. [144] comparatively studied the catalytic activity of electrochemically prepared MOOH films (M = Ni, Co, and Fe) on the FTO substrate for the electrochemical oxidation of HMF into FDCA using a three-electrode setup with 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. The investigation pointed out that NiOOH is the most active catalyst to achieve up to 96.0% FDCA yield and FE at 1.47 V vs RHE. HMF oxidation rate could be further increased by applying more positive potential, however, the FDCA yield and FE would decrease as the competitive water oxidation became an increasingly dominant reaction. Despite of the fact that CoOOH has the ability to initiate HMF oxidation at a less positive potential than NiOOH due to the Co2+/Co3+ conversion occurring at a less positive potential, the Co(OH)2/CoOOH mediated HMF oxidation under constant potential was less efficient than Ni(OH)2/NiOOH-mediated HMF oxidation due to the slower kinetics and the fact that not all Co3+ sites in CoOOH could be used for the reversible catalytic cycles. Among the three catalysts, FeOOH films were not efficient for HMF oxidation as they did not exhibit any activity for HMF electrooxidation at potentials prior to water oxidation while only trace amounts of DFF, HMFCA, FFCA, and FDCA could be detected during constant potential HMF oxidation performed at 1.71 V. This observation also obtained the effect of the film thickness on the current generated by different oxidation pathways, contributing to a better understanding of the catalytic active sites and mechanisms of HMF oxidation on transition metal electrocatalysts in the alkaline system. For the sake of further reduction of the operating cost in product separation, electrochemical oxidation of HMF in acidic media was also explored by the same research group to enable FDCA spontaneous precipitation, due to the fact that FDCA precipitates out when the pH is below < 2–3 [150]. As a catalyst being highly stable in strong acid media under anodic bias and prefer HMF oxidation to water oxidation, the MnO x anode could oxidize both the –OH and –CHO groups of HMF to achieve 99% HMF conversion and 53.8% FDCA yield in a pH 1 H2SO4 solution by applying a potential of 1.6 V vs. RHE, whereas Pt electrode as contrast could oxidize the –OH group to generate DFF but was unable to catalyze the further oxidation to FDCA even at 2.0 V vs. RHE. One of the disadvantages of using acidic media is FDCA spontaneously precipitated out on the electrode surface during electrolysis, thereby hindering further electrochemical oxidation. The downside can be addressed by elevating reaction temperature to 60 °C to improve the solubility of FDCA, therefore a simple but efficient separation method was developed accordingly by altering the temperature instead of the solution pH. Another drawback of acidic electrolysis is the limited product selectivity due to the formation of about 20% yield of maleic acid, in spite of which is another biomass-derived platform molecule with wide industrial applications [150]. The promising ability to upgrade HMF into value-added chemicals in mild conditions by electrochemical oxidation instead of aerobic oxidation is already quite attractive, while more benefits arise when considering the integration of the anodic oxidation and cathodic reduction reactions. By coupling HMF oxidation to cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in a single electrolyzer, the integrated system can achieve higher utilization efficiency of input energy due to the more favorable thermodynamics of HMF oxidation than that of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in water. In addition, the bio-based products are undoubtedly more valuable than oxygen produced by OER and the potential risk by H2/O2 crossover will also be addressed, eliminating the need for costly separation membrane. From 2016, Ni2P nanoparticle arrays on nickel foam (Ni2P NPA/NF) [133], Co-P on copper foam (Co-P/CF) [134], hierarchically porous Ni3S2/Ni foam (Ni3S2/NF) [135], and hierarchically porous nickel-based electrocatalyst (hp-Ni) [136], were reported in succession as bifunctional electrocatalysts for HMF oxidation coupling with HER by Sun’s research group. Recently, Wang and co-workers [143] also put forward a strongly coupled Ni3N/carbon nanosheets (Ni3N@C) to proceed with the integration reactions, and evaluated the pathway of HMF oxidation by using sum frequency generation (SFG) vibrational spectroscopy. For all bifunctional electrocatalysts, by passing stoichiometric charge, HMF converted completely to achieve about 98% and 90% yields of FDCA on Ni-based electrodes and Co-P/CF, respectively. The substitution of OER by HMF oxidation enabled the cell voltage significantly reduced by more than 200 mV, demonstrating much better energy conversion efficiency of the integration system relative to water splitting alone. Due to the absence of separation membrane, the possible electro-reduction of reducible –CHO group of HMF is a competitive reaction with HER and thus will appreciably lower the selectivity and faradaic efficiency of cathodic reaction. However, all the four catalysts mentioned above showed nearly 100% FE toward cathodic hydrogen evolution, suggesting there was only water reduction to H2 on the cathode. This result is relative to the fact that the conversion of HMF are highly dependent on the pH of electrolyte, while electrochemical reduction or hydrogenation of HMF were often reported in acidic [151] or neutural [152] environment. Despite hydrogen generation is more favorable in acidic media than in alkaline media, the combination of HMF oxidation with HER in the acidic electrolyte is rarely reported. we recently reported Co3O4 nanowires as highly efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts for simultaneous oxidation HMF into FDCA and production of hydrogen from water splitting using a similar integration strategy (Fig. 10 ) [153]. Through a facile hydrothermal reaction and subsequent low-temperature pyrolysis, the well-constructed Co3O4 nanowires with pine needle-like shape were in-situ anchored on nickel foam to form 3D monolithic electrode (CoNW/NF). The defective feature of nanowire array with abundant crystals and interconnected pores enabled CoNW/NF with excellent electrocatalytic performance. For OER alone, the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curve recorded on CoNW/NF showed 1.563 V vs RHE at the characteristic current density of 10 mA cm−2, superior to most of OER catalysts based on transition metals. After adding HMF to reach 100 mM, the required potential at the benchmark 10 mA cm−2 current density was just 1.269 V vs RHE with the corresponding Tafel plots of 125 mV dec-1, demonstrating the highly thermodynamic and kinetic activities of the as-synthesized CoNW/NF catalyst. To our best knowledge, the result is still superior to the vast majority of the reported catalysts for electrooxidation of HMF, such as Ni2P NPA/NF (1.35 V vs RHE at onset) [133], Ni3S2/NF (1.35 V vs RHE at onset) [135], Co-P/CF (1.30 V vs RHE at onset) [134], hp-Ni (~1.35 V vs RHE at onset) [136], Ni x B/NF (1.38 V vs RHE at onset) [137], Nano-Cu foam (1.25 V vs RHE at onset) [146], NiCo2O4/NF (~1.36 V vs RHE for 10 mA cm−2) [140], NiFe LDH (1.25 V vs RHE at onset) [127], CuNi(OH)2/C (1.45 V vs RHE for 9.2 mA cm−2) [147], NiSe@NiO x (1.35 V vs RHE at onset) [148], and MoO2-FeP@C (1.323 V vs RHE at onset) [154]. For HER, the cathodic LSV curves exhibited no visible difference with and without HMF participation even the concentration of HMF up to 100 mM, contrasted to the situation of NF with 14 mV negative shift when 100 mM presented, indicating CoNW catalyst-equipped with a high preference for hydrogen formation rather than the possible reduction of aldehyde groups of HMF and intermediates. Further product analysis revealed that, 100% HMF conversion and H2 evolution FE, as well as 96.8% yield and 96.6% FE toward FDCA production, were achieved on the 3D CoNW/NF catalyst in individual three-electrode reactions. More importantly, the pine needle–like features displayed excellent structural stability and robust catalytic durability for five successive electrolysis cycles for ~ 30 h in total. For the integration of HMF oxidation and HER, the two-electrode system containing 1.0 M KOH and 100 mM HMF required a cell voltage of only 1.504 V to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2, reducing by 362 mV in comparison with that of water oxidation. On account of such catalytic activities, the energy-saving coupling configuration was also visually demonstrated by using a commercial 1.5 V battery as a driven force, unambiguously verifying the concept of energy barrier reduction by substitution OER with HMF oxidation. Except for the substitution of OER by HMF oxidation on the anode, the cathodic HER in the coupling system can also be replaced by hydrogenation [155–158] of HMF or other organic molecules, arising a new route to the paired electrosynthesis by using water as an oxygen and hydrogen source. For instance, Wang and co–workers [142] recently succeeded in simultaneous electrocatalytic oxidation (ECO) and electrocatalytic hydrogenation (ECH) of HMF into FDCA and 2,5-bishydroxymethyl-tetrahydrofuran (DHMTHF), respectively, by using a membrane electrode assembly electrolyzer. As depicted in Fig. 11 , the core of the paired electrosynthesis system was actually a membrane reactor consisting of two separate compartments and a bipolar membrane, achieving entirely different electrochemical environments due to the excellent tolerance of the membrane to different pH values. Vanadium nitride (VN) and Pd/VN were sprayed on both sides of the bipolar membrane to act as ECO catalyst and ECH catalyst, respectively. By employing two pumps to separately circulate the anolyte and catholyte, the paired electrolyzer realized 92% and 87% conversions, as well as ~ 89% and ~ 77% yields, for HMF oxidation and hydrogenation, respectively. Although two catalysts were incorporated into a bipolar membrane to form an electrode assembly, rather than one component acted as a bifunctional catalyst, the 3D hollow nanosphere structure of VN played a critical role in the diffusion and transportation of the substrate in both ECO and ECH reactions. On the other hand, for the situation of furfural without –CH2OH attached to the furan ring, Zhao et al. [159] recently found the carbon fiber cloth supported Cu3P nanosheets and granular Ni2P nanocrystals (Cu3P/CFC and Ni2P/CFC, respectively) were of electrocatalytic activities for both furfural hydrogenation reaction (FHR) and furfural oxidation reaction (FOR) in alkaline media. Due to the fact that Ni2P/CFC is more favorable for FOR and Cu3P/CFC is more favorable for FHR, a two-electrode H-type electrocatalysis cell assembled with Ni2P/CFC as anode and Cu3P/CFC as cathode was constructed for simultaneous electrosynthesis of furfuryl alcohol and furoic acid with ~ 100% selectivity in 1 M KOH solution, demonstrating high FE of 97%–99%. By applying NiB x as a bifunctional catalyst in 1 M KOH electrolyte, Sun et al. [139] also progressed in paired electrolysis for the simultaneous oxidation of HMF to FDCA and hydrogenation of p-nitrophenol to p-aminophenol, acquiring ≥ 99% conversion efficiency and selectivity. Qin et al. [160] recently reported a novel B and N codoped porous carbon (BNC) as the first metal-free electrocatalyst for HMF oxidation coupling with N2 reduction reaction (NRR). After 6 h electrolysis at a relatively high anode potential of 1.9 V vs RHE, FDCA was successfully obtained with a yield of 57% at 71% conversion of HMF. However, among these paired electrolysis systems, the shuttles or crossover of organic substrates and intermediates even products often cause serious side reactions thus lower the FE of objective reactions, arousing the use of separate membrane again. Table 6 enumerates the representative electrochemical oxidations of HMF. The conversion and yield, as well as FE toward FDCA production, given in the table are the best achieved under the desired conditions. 4 Photoelectrocatalytic and photocatalytic oxidation of HMF 4.1 Photoelectrocatalytic oxidation Considering the inexhaustible solar energy, it is undoubtedly more attractive to accomplish HMF oxidation and H2 production by directly introducing external light as the energy source to the above electrolysis, instead of electrolysis powered by photovoltaic electricity. In 2015, Choi et al. [161] constructed a photoelectrochemical cell (PEC) with 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine 1-oxyl (TEMPO) as a mediator and catalyst to utilize solar energy for HMF photooxidation and H2 generation. In the fabricated PEC, the nanoporous n-type BiVO4 photoanode generated and separated hole-electron pairs under simulated solar illumination. The photogenerated holes oxidized TEMPO to TEMPO+, which was highly active to oxidize HMF to form final FDCA in alkaline media, whereas the photoexcited electrons were transferred to the Pt counter electrode by external bias to reduce water to H2. The high FE and yield for FDCA formation, up to 93% and 99%, respectively, indicated that TEMPO-mediated HMF oxidation was kinetically much faster than OER and was the dominant oxidation reaction, even in the pure electrocatalytic reaction [162]. The vital role of BiVO4 is providing a suitable valence-band (VB) to generate holes to initiate TEMPO oxidation, demonstrated by the photocurrent onset potential was shifted to 0.32 V vs RHE while the electrochemical onset potential was 1.01 V vs RHE. Motivated by substituting the kinetically unfavorable OER and producing value-added FDCA in PECs, Li and co-workers [163] recently reported a cobalt phosphate (CoPi) modified BiVO4 to further improve the performance of TEMPO-mediated HMF oxidation. The authors confirmed the heterostructured BiVO4/CoPi photoanodes and the electrodeposition time was a critical parameter for controlling the thickness of CoPi and thus selectively promoting TEMPO oxidation. BiVO4/CoPi prepared by a 30 min CoPi deposition (BiVO4/CoPi-30) was found to reduce the potential required for TEMPO oxidation by about 0.5 V, as well as improve the charge injection efficiency sevenfold compared to bare BiVO4. Furthermore, O2 was not detected for BiVO4/CoPi-30, suggesting the greater selectivity towards TEMPO oxidation without any faradaic efficiency loss to OER. Transient photocurrent measurements demonstrated that CoPi inhibited solution-mediated recombination resulting from the back reduction of oxidized TEMPO, which was identified as the bottleneck factor for BiVO4 performance. Although the above two works opened up a bright future for exploration of rationally-designed photoanodes and new reaction routes to more fully and efficiently utilize renewable solar energy and renewable feedstocks, the drawback of TEMPO-mediated method cannot be ignored. Compared to pure electrochemical oxidation, the additional requirement of a greater proportion of TEMPO (≥1 equivalent) for higher FDCA yield makes the TEMPO-mediated process highly expensive. Moreover, due to the good solubility of TEMPO, the separation and purification of final FDCA from homogeneous TEMPO are difficult. Immobilization of TEMPO on heterogeneous supports will reduce these barriers. In addition, the reported high yield and FE toward FDCA yield are based on a low initial concentration of HMF, so the photoelectrochemical field is critical to developing more robust catalysts to efficiently convert HMF to FDCA. 4.2 Photocatalytic oxidation On account of the overpotential for photoanode oxidation is determined by the VB edge position of semiconductor and the role of the applied bias for PEC is only to enhance the separation of photogenerated hole-electron to make more holes available for oxidation, it is possible to develop better photocatalysts to achieve pure photocatalysis without external bias and TEMPO. In 2017, Zhang et al. [81] exploited a hybrid photocatalyst for the selective oxidation of HMF into FDCA by immobilizing cobalt thioporphyrazine (CoPz) on g-C3N4 (CoPz/g-C3N4) (Fig. 12 a). The biomimetic CoPz itself has some unique capacity in photocatalytic activation of triplet oxygen (3O2) to generate singlet oxygen (1O2), which has appropriate oxidizing power to convert HMF into the desirable FDCA. Nevertheless, CoPz molecules are prone to aggregate in aqueous solution due to their hydrophobicity, reducing the contact between the catalyst and HMF reactant and thus giving a very modest catalytic performance with 40.2% conversion and 36.2% yield after 14 h UV–visible irradiation (300–1000 nm Xe light, 0.5 W/cm2). On the other hand, semiconductive g-C3N4 is often used as an active photocatalyst for water splitting and pollution degradation. However, no furan product could be detected at HMF conversion of 99.6% when g-C3N4 used as photocatalyst alone, which means that the pure g-C3N4 is not suitable for the selective oxidation due to the degradation of HMF to CO2 and H2O by the g-C3N4 generated hydroxyl radicals (HO•). After dispersed CoPz on g-C3N4, the strong interaction between the two components not only improves accessibility and 1O2 generation ability of the CoPz sites but also suppresses the HO• generation by g-C3N4, significantly enhancing the photocatalytic performance to obtain 96.1% FDCA yield under the same irradiation conditions using air as a benign oxidant. In addition, the pH value of the reaction system has been found to play a critical influence on the selectivity of the final oxidation products (Fig. 12b-d). At pH = 9.18 or 6.86, the main product after 14 h reaction was FDCA with high selectivity more than 95%, while at pH = 4.01 HMF selective produced DFF with a yield of above 80%. Combined that the selectivities of DFF at the initial 2 h were more than 45% in the three reaction systems with different pH values, the photocatalysis on CoPz/g-C3N4 was inferred to undergo DFF-intermediated route and possible to select the final product by adjusting the reaction system pH. Analogous regulation of product by control of pH was also reported later by Sun et al. [164], who ascribed the results to the Cannizzaro mechanism that –CHO groups will disproportionate to form corresponding –OH and –COOH in alkaline environment. Using Ni decorated ultrathin 2D CdS nanosheets (Ni/CdS) as a photocatalyst, the authors developed a photocatalytic integration strategy to efficiently utilize the photoexcited holes and electrons to oxidize biomass substrates and simultaneously reduce protons to H2, respectively (Fig. 12e). Under the visible light irradiation (440–460 nm blue LED, 8 W) for 2 h, HMF was utterly transformed to FDCA with concomitant generation of H2 in the presence of 1000 equiv. NaOH, while furfural alcohol exhibited a faster oxidation to yield over 90% furoic acid in only 1 h under the same conditions (Fig. 12f-h).
