Further control experiments with 2,5-dihydroxymethylfurfural (DHMF) and HMFCA as reaction substrates verified that, the presence of an –CHO group seemed to impede the oxidation of –OH attached to the furan ring, whereas ancillary –OH and –COOH groups did not present any negative impact. More importantly, according to the results of photoluminescence and 1H NMR detection, almost no HO• radicals were generated during the photocatalysis process, which is highly consistent with the situation of CoPz/g-C3N4. In addition, the negative impact of HO• radicals can also be revealed by the partial oxidation of HMF on a composite photocatalyst of ZnO and polypyrrole (ZnO/PPy) in pH = 7.8 water solution [165]. The presence of HO• radicals on the surface of the ZnO/PPy photocatalyst was proved by the determination with terephthalic acid. Under the visible light irradiation by a 15 W LED for 6 h, the conversion of HMF was 5% and 30% at 25 and 40 °C, while the selectivity of FDCA was reduced from 30 to 18%, respectively. The decreased selectivity to HMFCA, DFF, and FDCA indicates that the increase of photocatalysis temperature is unfavorable for any desirable furan products, which is mainly due to the non-selective oxidation by the highly reactive radicals became more intense at the higher temperature to crack the furan ring even mineralize HMF. The photoelectrocatalytic and photocatalytic performance of HMF oxidation into FDCA are enumerated in Table 7 . 5 Mechanism of catalytic oxidation of HMF As shown in Scheme 1, the liquid phase oxidation of HMF over supported metal catalysts is a parallel-consecutive process, which is mainly due to the hydroxyl group and aldehyde group on furan ring equipped with close initial oxidation potential (the former is 0.55 V and the latter is 0.58 V vs. RHE on the Pd/C electrode) [63]. Additionally, the surface chemistry of catalysts can obviously affect the adsorption of HMF on the catalyst, thus affecting the subsequent catalytic reactions. A large number of researchers monitored the concentration variation of HMF, detectable intermediates (DFF, HMFCA, and FFCA) and final product FDCA, to deduce the catalytic oxidation routes. However, most of them failed to put forward a definite and convincing reaction mechanism so far. Recent advances in the oxidation mechanism of HMF have made significant and substantial progress by means of isotope labeling technology. In 2012, Davis et al. [166] studied the mechanism of HMF oxidation into FDCA over supported Au and Pt catalysts using isotope labeling. The aerobic oxidation of HMF catalyzed by Au/TiO2 at 22 °C and 345 kPa O2 with 2 equivalents of NaOH gave more than 98% selectivity of HMFCA after 6 h. To figure out the role of O2, the oxidation of HMF was performed using 18O2 as an oxidant, but there was no detectable 18O in the product HMFCA. As a comparison, the oxidation of HMF was undertaken in the H2 18O solvent. As expected, 1 18O atom was incorporated into HMFCA. The results revealed that water was the source of oxygen atoms in HMF oxidation through the catalytic conversion of hydroxide. First, a geminal diol was formed via the nucleophilic addition of a hydroxide ion from water to the carbonyl (Fig. 13 , step 1). Then OH– promoted O–H and C–H bond activation of the alcohol side chain of HMF in the presence of Au or Pt metal catalysts (Fig. 13, steps 2, 3) and at last oxidized aldehyde intermediates analogously to step 1 and 2 to form final diacid products (Fig. 13, steps 4, 5). The above pathway of HMF oxidation was often proposed in the similar aqueous alkaline system catalyzed by Au, Pt, Pd, and their alloys, mainly based on the intermediate products that were detected to be HMFCA and FFCA. However, the reaction pathway of aerobic oxidation of HMF was somewhat different when the reaction conditions changed, such as catalysis by Ru catalysts [33,115,123], absence of base additives, use of organic solvents. In 2014, Siankevich et al. [167] studied the oxidation mechanism of HMF catalyzed by Pt nanoparticles in water using 18O isotope labeling technology with the kinetic method. It was found that DFF and FFCA appeared in the oxidation reaction and HMFCA was not observed in the base-free system. As illustrated in Fig. 14 , 18O atoms supplemented in the intermediates DFF, FFCA and final product FDCA were derived from the labeled H2 18O. Molecular O2 was essential for HMF oxidation by scavenging electrons and the degraded pathway components from catalyst surface and thus enhancing the rates of each catalytic step. Besides reaction pathways, unraveling elementary steps and kinetic parameters is another key to understanding catalytic reaction mechanisms. Recently, Ferreira et al. [53] conducted a kinetics investigation for HMF oxidation to FDCA based on a Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson (LHHW) mechanism and pseudo-equilibrium approach. A continuous process in a trickle-bed reactor was used to investigate the aqueous phase oxidation over Ru/Al2O3 in aqueous Na2CO3 feed. The sequence of elementary steps for the HMF oxidation was proposed in Table 8 considering metallic Ru0 species as the single active site (σ). Considering the similar reaction pathway (HMF → HMFCA → FFCA → FDCA), the apparent activation energies for the oxidation of HMF, HMFCA, and FFCA, were estimated to be 32.1 kJ/mol, −25.1 kJ/mol, 58.7 kJ/mol, respectively. The model provided much higher values for k 2 than for k 1, due to HMFCA was consumed quickly. At the optimized temperature of 140 °C, k 3 got to a higher value than k 1, indicating that high temperatures were needed to over the energy barrier for the final oxidation. The obtained activation energies and rate constants confirmed that the oxidation of FFCA to FDCA was the rate-limiting step in the reaction, which agreed with the observed product distribution. The type and concentration of base played a significant role in the initial dehydrogenation step, whereas high oxygen pressure favored to achieve a high selectivity toward FDCA. However, Liu et al. [33] reported a different kinetic study on Ru/C involving DFF intermediate, rather than HMFCA. The rate constants revealed the FFCA oxidation to FDCA was much smaller (2.49 × 10-6 s−1) than those of HMF oxidation to DFF and DFF to FFCA (9.15 × 10-5 s−1, 8.05 × 10-5 s−1, respectively). Accordingly, the activation energies of the three oxidation steps were 52.5, 34.2, and 38.6 kJ/mol, respectively. Although HMFCA was not detected as intermediate, the oxidation of FFCA to FDCA was still the rate-determining step to dictate the formation rate of FDCA from HMF. The results were consistent somewhat with the previous study by Besson et al., using a power-law model to fit experimental data on Pt/TiO2 catalyst [37]. Under base-free conditions, the oxidation occurred mainly by the oxidative dehydrogenation of –CH2OH of HMF to form –CHO as the major products were DFF and FFCA. Increasing amounts of the base not only neutralized –COOH but also accelerated the oxidation rates of –CHO in the intermediates to the final FDCA. The higher rate constant for HMF oxidation to DFF than to HMFCA suggested the predominant formation of the DFF intermediate in this system. However, –CHO reacts very rapidly in basic solution to yield FFCA and thus the concentration of DFF is often very low, consisting with the high turnover frequency of 48 h−1 for DFF compared with 4 h−1 for HMF [36]. Using MFe2O4 (M = Cu, Mn, Co, Mg) as catalysts along with t-BuOOH as a stoichiometric oxidant without external base additive, Yadav et al. [44] analyzed the kinetics of HMF oxidation and pointed out that the oxidation of –CH2OH to –CHO is faster than oxidation of –CHO to –COOH. Above all, the reaction pathway and rates are very sensitive to the catalyst nature and reaction environment. Taking into consideration of the fact that the pathway of HMF oxidation was usually interpreted based on ex-situ detection and the essence of a redox reaction is electron transfer, it is reasonable to investigate the relationship of the conversion intermediates with the potential of the HMF electrooxidation by in situ technique. Very recently, Wang et al. [143] studied the conversion path of HMF on Ni3N@C electrocatalyst in 1.0 M KOH, via an in-situ sum frequency generation (SFG) vibrational spectroscopy to observe the change of organic species in during the electrocatalytic oxidation (Fig. 15 ). The in situ SFG approach is a second-order nonlinear optical technique with interface selectivity and sensitivity, and very suitable for identifying the molecular structure at the interface without influence from the electrode. After running the electrolysis at different potentials for 90 min, the SFG spectrum revealed that HMF was stable at the potential below 1.25 V, and began to oxidize to HMFCA when the potential reached to 1.35 V. As the potential increased to 1.45 V, the dominated 1335 cm−1 peak accompanied by the red-shift of the C=O stretching band was assigned to the formation of FFCA or FDCA. At 1.75 V, the product appeared almost characteristic peaks identical to pure FDCA with C=O stretching peak at around 1610 cm−1, suggesting the conversion of HMF was completed to the final FDCA rather than stayed at the intermediate FFCA step. For the constant potential electrolysis at 1.45 V, the characteristic peaks of HMFCA appeared at 15 min and strengthened to the most significant at 35 min. As the electrolysis time continued to increase, the peak of the intermediate product gradually disappeared, and the peak intensity of FDCA increased to reach a constant level after 90 min. The in situ SFG results were well consistent with the HPLC analysis, verifying that the HMF electrolysis underwent the HMFCA pathway. Although some important information about the production of FDCA from HMF oxidation in the base or base-free system is acquired by isotope labeling technique, elementary steps modeling, and in situ SFG approach. It is necessary to use other advanced technologies, such as in-situ electron microscopy and surface chemistry, to further investigate the details of the reaction interfaces and the intrinsic kinetics, as well as the structure–activity relationship. In addition, the oxidation path and kinetics in acidic media have rarely been studied. A comprehensive understanding of the reaction mechanism helps to rationally design more efficient and stable catalysts for HMF oxidation. 6 Conclusions and outlook Catalytic synthesis of high value-added chemicals from biomass-derived platform chemicals is not only objectively necessary but also actually possible to reduce current dependence on fossil-fuel resources. Efficient oxidation of HMF into FDCA in a heterogeneous manner mainly proceeds through thermocatalytic, electrocatalytic, and photocatalytic techniques. These catalysis strategies have their own advantages and disadvantages. Thermocatalysis is more commonly used compared to other strategies due to its efficient and convenient procedures. Besides, there are more candidate catalysts to choose for thermocatalysis in alkaline and neutral even acidic mediates, including highly active metals and metal-free carbon catalysts. However, the degradation of the substrate HMF will exacerbate as thermocatalysis often operated at the elevated reaction temperature. Electrocatalytic oxidation is a cleaner and safer method for FDCA production because it eliminates the use of high-pressure oxidizing atmosphere or other environmentally unfriendly chemical oxidants. Driven by the external potential, electrocatalysis shows significant advantages to utilize cheap transition metals as highly active catalysts and solve the thermodynamic and/or kinetic issues in thermocatalysis and photocatalysis. By controlling the electrode potential and circuit current, the management of electrocatalytic reaction parameters can be realized more accurately and conveniently compared to thermocatalysis. Despite many distinct advantages, what we should not ignore is that the conductive electrolyte is often a necessity for electrocatalysis due to the poor conductivity of HMF aqueous solution, causing energy consumption for product separation in the downstream processes compared to base-free heterogeneous catalysis. Photocatalytic and photoelectrocatalytic oxidations have a natural advantage in energy injection because of the use of photon rather than thermal and electrical energy. However, it is very challenging to design and screen efficient photocatalyst with suitable structures for conversion HMF into the desired product. The photogenerated holes and the derivative radicals have a high potential to oxidize organics till completely mineralize to CO2 [168], whereas photocatalytic HMF-to-FDCA conversion just requires moderately active species such as singlet oxygen to achieve the selective oxidation. Therefore, the core of photocatalysis is to improve the selectivity toward the target products. Overall, the laboratory-scale investigation of HMF oxidation has been relatively abundant, with transferring from traditional homogeneous base systems to heterogeneous base even to base-free systems, gradually realizing the goal of green and sustainable chemistry. But so far, the industrially large-scale and economical oxidation of HMF into FDCA still needs to be improved. More effort should be devoted to the development of highly efficient and economical catalysts, optimization of the reaction process, as well as isolation and purification of products. First, the activity of non-noble metal catalysts and the stability of noble metal catalysts need to be improved, which are very important for the practical prospects of FDCA production. Second, solvent and base play a crucial role in the reaction pathway and product distribution of HMF oxidation. Although the main oxidative product in the aqueous phase is often FDCA, the decrease in the selectivity of the target product caused by side reactions or competing reactions should not be neglected. Basic additives provide high yields and selectivities to FDCA with fast rates but more complex downstream separations, whereas reactions in neutral systems often suffer serious hold-up and product inhibition due to insoluble FDCA covering on the catalyst [124]. Third, the batch stirring tank reactor was applied in most reports [43,169–171], but there are some shortcomings, such as inconvenient operation, low productivity, and lower economy. For the sake of continuous and large-scale production in the future, gas–liquid-solid three phases fixed-bed reaction process is an alternative technology worth studying to overcome the above disadvantages of batch reaction. Fourth, the development of electrochemical oxidation is expected to change the overall situation of traditional thermal catalysis, but how to exclude the use of high-concentration base or acid electrolytes is still a long way to go. Fifth, the activity of metal-free catalysts needs to be greatly improved, and it is also an important aspect to develop high-efficiency activity regulation methods, such as introducing light and microwave into the reaction system. Sixth, from the economic perspective, HMF as a substrate is still too expensive to produce furan derivates. Biomass carbohydrates, such as glucose, fructose, and cellulose, are of great significance in the synthesis of FDCA, which has also received great attention and is facing many challenges in a complex operation and low yields. Last but not least, a comprehensive understanding of the reaction mechanisms of HMF oxidation is one of the most important research cores in the biomass conversion field, which helps to create original innovations in catalyst design and reaction engineering. Chunlin Chen received his Ph.D. in Industrial Catalysis in 2013 from the South China University of Technology and the Institute of Metal Research, CAS. Currently, he is an Associate Professor at the Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology & Engineering, CAS. His research focuses on carbon nanomaterials and heterogeneous catalysis. Lingchen Wang received her M.S. degree in 2018 from the Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology & Engineering, CAS and the Shanghai University. Currently, she is a Process Integration Engineer in the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, Ltd. Bin Zhu received his Bachelor degree from the Hefei University of Technology in 2017. He is currently pursuing his Master degree in Chemical Engineering at Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology & Engineering, CAS. His research work focuses on biomass conversion using electrochemical approaches. Zhenqiang Zhou received his Bachelor degree from the Shandong Agricultural University in 2017. He is currently pursuing his Master degree in Materials Engineering at Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology & Engineering, CAS. His research work focuses on biomass conversion using electrochemical approaches. Soliman I. El-Hout received his Ph.D. in 2018 in Physical Chemistry through a Joint program from The University of Suez, Egypt and the University of Okayama, Japan. Currently, he is an Assistant Professor at Nanostructured and Nanotechnology Division, Advanced Materials Department, Central Metallurgical R &D Institute, Egypt. His current research interests are in the synthesis of carbon-based nanocomposites for energy storage, water splitting, and heterogeneous catalysis. Jie Yang received her M.S. degree from China University of Petroleum (Hua Dong) in 2015. She currently works as an engineer at the Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology & Engineering, CAS. Her research work focuses on the aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural. Jian Zhang received his Ph.D. in 2006 from the Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, CAS, and then moved to the Fritz Haber Institute (FHI) of the Max Planck Society as a postdoctoral fellow and project leader in the Department of Inorganic Chemistry. Currently, He is a Professor at the Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology & Engineering, CAS. His research interests include carbon nanomaterials, metal-free catalysis, and environmental catalysis.

coredata.dc:description: Biomass conversion to value-added chemicals has received tremendous attention for solving global warming issues and fossil fuel depletion. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is a key bio-based platform molecule to produce many useful organic chemicals by oxidation, hydrogenation, polymerization, and ring-opening reactions. Among all derivatives, the oxidation product 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) is a promising alternative to petroleum-based terephthalic acid for the synthesis of biodegradable plastics. This review analytically discusses the recent progress in the thermocatalytic, electrocatalytic, and photocatalytic oxidation of HMF into FDCA, including catalyst screening, synthesis processes, and reaction mechanism. Rapid fundamental advances may be possible in non-precious metal and metal-free catalysts that are highly efficient under the base-free conditions, and external field-assisted processes like electrochemical or photoelectrochemical cells.
